newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan government adopts draft law on regions.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan government adopts draft law on regions.

text.p: Morocco has approved a draft law to set up elected powerful councils in the country's 16 regions, including the disputed Western Sahara, aimed at giving all people a voice in daily economic and financial management.

The official MAP news agency quoted the Interior Minister Driss Basri on Wednesday as saying the draft was examined and approved by a cabinet meeting presided by the Prime Minister Abdellatif Filali on Tuesday.
"The draft aims to respond to Moroccan people demands...and efforts of King Hassan to modernise the country and meet the challenges of the 21th century," MAP quoted Basri as saying.
The 70-articles draft law is expected to be discussed by the 333-seat parliament soon, MAP said.
The change is part of the constitutional reforms adopted earlier this year including the establishment of a bi-cameral parliament to be elected in 1997.
"Within the decentralisation, the region will be managed by a regional council elected for a period of six years," Basri said.
The council's decision will be carried out by the interior ministry representatives, including the governors, MAP said.
According to the new law, the state will transfer some of its financial powers such as tax collection and means to build schools and hospitals.
The government plans to create a special fund for the development of the poor regions, MAP said.

Earlier the authorities published the list of the new regional cut up as follows: Tangier-Tetouan, Hoceima-Taza, Fes- Boulemane, Meknes-Tafilalt, Tadla Atlas Central, Centre- Atlantique, Rabat-Khemisset, Casablanca, Oriental, Tensift, Chaouia-Ourdigha, Gharb, Souss-Massa-Draa, Guelmime-Smara, Laayoune-Boujdour and Oued Eddahab.
